posts.name: Haluk A. I.
posts.cooked:
Hey there, I am looking for a nice usb camera to use with an Orange Pi 5 to detect notes on the field.

I canâ€™t  decide the horizontal angle to go with. Iâ€™m afraid that too large FOV would create distortion and cause the AI to fail detecting.

But I also wanâ€™t to have a wide angle one so it can easily see notes around it. I want to know whatâ€™s the  maximum.

Any suggestions?

Thanks

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Whatever you get, youâ€™ll likely want to ensure it has a global shutter

posts.name: Haluk A. I.
posts.cooked: Ok, I will be careful with that. I canâ€™t decide the horizontal angle to go with tho.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
We use a USB camera from ELP with a 3.6mm lens.  I think the resulting HFOV is 84 degrees.  This works well for our use of vision-assisted driving to notes.  We donâ€™t try to make vision corrections until we are about 3 feet from the note.  If you are trying to identify multiple notes on the field and set a longer path to them, you might want more HFOV than we use.

Related to the earlier comment about global shutter, be aware that global shutter cameras are more likely to be grayscale than rolling shutter cameras.  You almost certainly will want a color sensor for note detection (or other future game pieces).  Adding color to shape is going to help detection whether you are using deep learning models or something simpler.  If you think you want global shutter just make sure itâ€™s also a color camera.

posts.name: Haluk A. I.
posts.cooked: Thanks for the suggestion! And also, we made the mistake of accidentally ordering a grayscale global shutter camera actually It is a spare apriltag cam now.

posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked: Tell me more. I thought global shutter just coordinated shutter across multiple cameras. How does global shutter improve the image of a single camera?

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: Global shutter is a method of capturing the pixels that make up a single frame. With global shutter, the whole frame is captured at once, as opposed to rolling shutter where the frame is captured line by line top to bottom. The reason you want global shutter is because rolling shutter can distort the image when thereâ€™s motion, making it hard for the object detection to understand what itâ€™s seeing

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: A suggested AprilTag filter is throw away images if the robot velocity is greater than some (fairly low) speed. With a global shutter camera that is essentially a non-issue. The differences are amazing (albeit may not always be important).

posts.name: Rocky
posts.cooked:
You can callibrate the camera to get rid of the distortion. Hereâ€™s our vision code we used this year, camera calibration code included
